awd_titl_txt: Advancing and Representing Research Across the Spectrum of Mechanics Nationally and Internationally: The U.S. National Committee on Theoretical and Applied Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the U.S. Committee on Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (USNC/TAM), organized and supported by the National Academy of Sciences (NAS). The committee will represent the U.S. in the International Union of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (IUTAM) and serve as a focal point to chart future priorities in mechanics based research, applications and education. USNC/TAM promotes new research directions and provides opportunities and experiences for both practitioners and early career faculty in the field of mechanics. USNC/TAM will encourage, foster and facilitate activities that engage U.S. scientists and engineers domestically and internationally. The Committee also advances the economic competitiveness of the U.S. through a comprehensive series of activities that focus on diverse groups such as early career researchers. Interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary research and an improvement in racial and gender diversity of the committee are additional foci for this effort. Thus, through these efforts, USNC/TAM will promote the progress of the field of mechanics; advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and secure the national defense.

This award supports the core functions of the USNC/TAM including IUTAM dues, travel support to the biannual IUTAM General Assemblies, and support for an annual USNC/TAM committee meeting. Specific opportunities to be enabled by the Committee include the U.S. National Congresses of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics, National Academies' workshops, IUTAM and AmeriMech symposia, travel experiences, and mentoring breakfasts for early career researchers. The Committee will also reach out to diverse communities through videos in YouTube and Vimeo, social media announcements, professional society newsletters, and livestreaming workshops.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Academy of Sciences (NAS) obtained a three-year award (#1742900) for Advancing and Representing Research Across the Spectrum of Mechanics Nationally and Internationally: The U.S. National Committee on Theoretical and Applied Mechanics.  The U.S. National Committee for Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (USNC/TAM) plays two important roles: (1) represent the U.S. in the International Union for Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (IUTAM), and (2) serve as a focal point for charting future priorities in mechanics-related research, applications, and education in the United States.  This award supported the USNC/TAM core functions, which include: 1) IUTAM dues, 2) travel support for the U.S.-based President of IUTAM, five U.S. delegates, and one NAS staff to the biannual IUTAM General Assemblies, 3) support for an annual USNC/TAM committee meeting, and 4) NAS staff time.

Intellectual Merit

The USNC/TAM has increased:1) the representation in mechanics in the USNC/TAM, and 2) the outreach to the public and the broader mechanics community. Horacio Espinosa (Northwestern University) is the new Chair and Melany Hunt (Caltech), the incoming Vice Chair. Tom Pence (Michigan State University) is the incoming Secretary, and Sonya Smith (Howard University) is the new Professional Society Coordinator.  This is a new leadership position created as a result of an Ad-Hoc Committee on the Structure of the USNC/TAM chaired by Past Chair Beverley McKeon (institution here).  The Ad-Hoc Committee brought forward a series of changes to the USNC/TAM Constitution and By-Laws, which were accepted by unanimous vote during a special meeting held in April 2022.

The committee has developed a Distinguished Lecture Series in Mechanics. The objective of this series is to convey excitement, stimulate interest, and discuss opportunities in the mechanical sciences and engineering related to advances in infrastructure, automation, transportation, energy, bio-medicine, sustainability, exploration, and other areas.  The targeted audience includes students and teachers interested in STEM fields at high schools across the nation and the general public.  The lectures are free and open to the public.  The lecture was streamed live and archived for future use.  This activity is supported by private USNC/TAM funds. The inaugural lecture was given by Dr. Adam Steltzner of the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Chief Engineer for the Mars Perseverance rover and entitled ?Success and Failure on Mars: Mechanics in the Exploration of Space?.  The talk attracted over 500 live participants, ranging from high school students to the executive officer of one of our member societies.  The 2022 lecture was given by Prof. Peko Hosoi, the Neil and Jane Pappalardo Professor of Mechanical Engineering, Professor of Mathematics, and a core faculty member of the Institute for Data, Systems and Society at MIT.  She is the co-founder of the MIT Sports Lab, which connects the MIT community with pro-teams and industry partners to address data and engineering challenges that lie within the sports domain.  Her lecture, entitled ?The Mechanics of Sport,? was held via Zoom and drew over 100 participants.  

In August 22, 2020, the USNC/TAM conducted a Webinar on Machine Learning featuring domain experts from the U.S. that attracted over 500 participants.  The USNC/TAM Webinar on Art and Animation in Mechanics, held in August 2021, was also well-attended, especially by early career researchers; over two hundred and fifty attendees participated in the event.  

The 19th U.S. National Congress on Theoretical and Applied Mechanics took place on June 18-24, 2022 on the campus of The University of Texas at Austin, TX.  More than 750 participants attended in person, with several more sending recordings due to late health-related changes in availability. The USNC/TAM sponsored and led a special mini-symposium to mark one hundred years since Theodore von Karman proposed an international meeting in mechanics, which led to the formation of IUTAM.

The USNC/TAM held an online Mentoring Event the Friday before the Congress, with 45 early career researchers in attendance.  This event was part of a series designed to develop communications skills and professional development in early career researchers in mechanics.

The broader impacts of the committee include its leadership in the international union and mechanics at large.  The USNC/TAM works to maintain a number of leadership positions in the IUTAM.  Members of the committee represent the U.S. mechanics community internationally in the Bureau, General Assembly, and various committees of the IUTAM.  USNC/TAM members are very active in IUTAM, thereby reflecting the international status of the committee and participating in defining mechanics research and education directions, including capacity building in the international scene. In addition, the committee?s support early career mechanicians through its Congress Fellowship Program facilitates the recipients? interactions with researchers from around the world.

Professor Sonya Smith (Howard University) is the first holder of the professional society position, which is designed to improve outreach to underserved communities.  The USNC/TAM also continues producing a yearly newsletter to inform member societies and government contacts of USNC/TAM about its activities and priorities.
